body_text.text: Introduction Detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) in patient-derived bioaerosol is a potential tool to 48 measure source case infectiousness. However, current bioaerosol sampling approaches have reported low 49 detection yields in sputum-positive TB cases. To increase the utility of bioaerosol sampling, we present 50 advances in bioaerosol collection and Mtb identification that improve detection yields.

Methods A previously described Respiratory Aerosol Sampling Chamber (RASC) protocol, or "RASC-1", was 52 modified to incorporate liquid collection of bioaerosol using a high-flow wet-walled cyclone (RASC-2).

Individuals with GeneXpert-positive pulmonary TB were sampled pre-treatment over 60-minutes. Putative Mtb 54 bacilli were detected in collected fluid by fluorescence microscopy utilising DMN-Trehalose. Exhaled air and 55 bioaerosol volumes were estimated using continuous CO 2 monitoring and airborne particle counting, 56 respectively. Mtb capture was calculated per exhaled air volume sampled and bioaerosol volume for RASC-1 57 (n=35) and for RASC-2 (n=21). Empty chamber samples were collected between patients as controls.

Tuberculosis (TB) remains a serious global public health threat [1]. In 2018, the global incidence was estimated 72 at 10 million with a death toll of 1.5 million [2] . Driving the high burden is on-going transmission of infection, 73 as demonstrated by the 1.1 million cases of childhood TB disease globally. Preliminary results of sampling from both healthy controls and individuals with newly diagnosed pulmonary TB 105 are also presented.

Mounted within the chamber, the air enters the conical collector through a tangential nozzle. The high flow rate 127 of 250 L/min generates a liquid cyclone and particle inertia leads to deposition of bioaerosol from the airstream 128 onto the wet wall with a high collection efficiency. Collection into liquid has the advantage of minimizing 129 particle bounce, improving the recovery of viable Mtb bacilli and maximizing the air volume sampled over time.

This study has shown that, by optimising both bioaerosol collection and Mtb detection, a majority of newly 214 diagnosed GeneXpert sputum positive TB patients can be shown to exhale viable Mtb organisms. The increased 215 numbers of Mtb organisms captured by RASC-2 compared with RASC-1 were associated with an approximate 1 216 log 10 increase in exhaled air sampled and bioaerosol particle volume collected. This is not explained by 217 demographic and clinical characteristics which were broadly equivalent between the patients sampled by the 218 different methods. The resulting lowered limit of detection enabled identification of putative Mtb organisms in 219 95% of patients whose bacillary concentrations varied over a 2 log 10 range from 1 to 100 per 100 L exhaled air.

The proportion of patients identified with Mtb positive bioaerosols is therefore a function of lower level of 221 detection. However, exhaled particle volumes varied markedly between individuals, suggesting that infectivity 222 is likely to be impacted by both Mtb concentration of lung fluids and individual bioaerosol particle production. 223 All rights reserved. FIGREF1.text: 80 detecting transmission by the demonstration of new infection in the animals [4, 5]. Employing a sampling 81 system with physical separation of patients (source case) and guinea pigs (sampler) led to the confirmation of 82 airborne transmission. Moreover, intricate linking of individual patients to specific guinea pig infections by 83 bacillary resistance patterns and timing of entry and departure from the ward allowed for identification of a 84 minority of highly infectious 'super-spreaders'. The guinea pig model therefore supported the concepts that 85 infectiousness is highly heterogenous and that small bioaerosol -which arise as a consequence of dehydration 86 of buoyant airborne droplets during "aging" following release into the environment -are primarily responsible 87 for remote transmission [6]. 88 Invaluable though this contribution was to the early understanding of TB transmission, the experimental design 89 was not optimised for sensitive sampling [7]. Minimal sensitivity to Mtb production necessitates sampling 90 multiple patients for days to months for both historical and recent in vivo sampling experiments [8-10]. 91 However, some modern approaches with greater proximity between source case and sampler, single patient 92 sampling and viable organism detection have dramatically improved the overall detection sensitivity. Direct 93 detection has identified Mtb bacilli within only minutes to hours of sampling [11-13], generated individual-level 94 information, and found a greater proportion of emitters. 95 These sensitive techniques have the potential to efficiently answer questions regarding the transmission 96 potential of patient sub-groups and test strategies for transmission mitigation. Further sensitivity improvement 97 may allow investigation of Mtb-containing droplet release from patients across the TB disease spectrum, 98 including sputum smear-negative cases, HIV-coinfected and even subclinical TB cases. Sensitive sampling 99 combined with quantitative forms of detection also provide an infectivity measure. Such a measure could be 100 applied longitudinally to those receiving chemotherapy to more accurately establish time to bioaerosol 101 sterilisation with direct clinical application.102 All rights reserved. FIGREF2.text: Aerosol Sampling Chamber (RASC) is an enclosed, clean room optimised for the sampling of 108 aged bioaerosol from a single individual during a 60-minute period of natural respiratory activity. A previous 109 description of the RASC design, "RASC-1", has been published [14] in addition to results from a 35-patient 110 pulmonary TB sampling study [11]. The apparatus and sampling protocols employed for those initial studies is 111 referred to throughout this report as "RASC-1". The current study describes several design modifications, 112 informed by an iterative series of experiments, which have refined the apparatus and sampling protocol while 113 maintaining the basic structure of the chamber. This new version is referred to as "RASCan array of aerosol sample collection instruments operated consecutively at the peak of 116 chamber air contamination. This included polycarbonate, gelatin and felt filters, Dekati and Andersen impactors, 117 and a cyclone collector. The flow rates (chamber outflow) varied between instruments, subject to device 118 specifications. Both impactors and the polycarbonate and gelatin filters sampled with flow rates of 20-30 L/min, 119 whereas the felt filter and the cyclone collector sampled with higher flow rates: 300 and 250 L/min, 120 respectively. Results yielded no positive samples from the felt or gelatin filters. For the rest, no sampling 121 instruments demonstrated significantly higher yield per unit of exhaled air sampled. Therefore, to maximize the 122 exhaled air volume sampled, the sample collection process was simplified to a single cyclone collector. 123 Cyclone Collector 124 A high-efficiency cyclone collector (Coriolis μ air sampler, Bertin, Montigny le Bretonneux, France) was used 125 for RASC-2 to collect airborne bioaerosol into 5-10 mL of sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solution.

Consistent 226 with prior observations [6], these are the particles thought most likely to reach the peripheral lungs of 227 susceptible individuals sharing an indoor location [17]. It is also probable that these bioaerosols containing 228 viable Mtb organisms might be indicative of a wide range of source infectivity. The investigation of Mtb 229 production and, consequently, potential infectivity during various respiratory manoeuvres is under current 230 investigation in our laboratory. 231 The sensitive detection of individual Mtb organisms, with DMN-Trehalose staining and subsequent fluorescence 232 microscopy analysis, requires a high degree of sterility to exclude contamination during sampling and isolation. 233 After detailed analysis of the platform and collection equipment, we noted that the wet-walled cyclone 234 contained a dead space which was a potential reservoir for live Mtb cells. Therefore, the device was modified to 235 enable dismantling and autoclaving. The very low numbers of Mtb organisms detected during empty booth 236 sampling could also have resulted from the release of trapped Mtb organisms by the negative pressure inducing 237 retrograde airflow across the exit HEPA filter. Reassuringly, following modification of the collector and the 238 application of combined dry vapour hydrogen peroxide and ozone treatments of the RASC after use, of a sensitive and reproducible measure of Mtb in exhaled bioaerosols has enabled the 242 demonstration of a wide range of potential infectivity of newly diagnosed TB patients. Bioaerosol assays may 243 offer a useful adjunct to TB transmission studies, enabling demonstration of infectivity of sputum negative 244 individuals and the effect of specific chemotherapies on infectivity.
